Although the other views also occur in the presence of a body, they do not take on the characteristics of self and what belongs to self,

Although other views also arise in relation to the five aggregates, they do not calculate that they create and experience themselves,

Venerable Vasumitra says:

Answer: Because they are created by the power of one's own causes and conditions.
Because it is the result obtained from one's own karma and afflictions.
The questions and answers regarding extreme views are the same as before.
Why is it called extreme view?
It is called extreme view because this view grasps two extremes.
That is, it arises in relation to the two extremes of annihilation and permanence.
As a sutra says:
If the Katyayanas truly know and see the origination of the world with right wisdom,
they will not grasp it as nonexistent. Grasping it as nonexistent
is the view of annihilation.
That is, if they see the arising of a later body, they will think:
'Thus, sentient beings die here and are born there. This is definitely not annihilation.'
If they truly know and see the cessation of the world with right wisdom,
they will not grasp it as existent. Grasping it as existent
is the view of permanence.
That is, if they see the separate continuity of the aggregates, realms, and sense bases, they will think:
'Thus, sentient beings have birth and death. This is definitely not impermanence.' Furthermore, this view is called extreme view because what it grasps is extremely contemptible.
It is said that the non-Buddhists who grasp at a real self are already foolish and vulgar.
How much more so for grasping at a self as either annihilated or eternal, which is not a borderland.
Furthermore, this view is called extreme view because it grasps at the extreme of the most distant.
It is said that the non-Buddhists grasp at a real self.
They are already at the extreme of the principle of no-self.
How much more so for grasping at a self as either annihilated or eternal, which is not the extreme.
Furthermore, this grasping is called extreme view because it operates with the characteristics of grasping at the two extremes.
It is said that it operates with the characteristics of grasping at annihilation and eternity.

What is the meaning of what is said in this sutra?
Venerable Vasumitra says:
The World-Honored One definitely speaks of cause and effect.
It is said that if the Buddha encounters non-Buddhists who hold the view of eternalism, they say that all dharmas have effects but no causes.
Because there are no causes,
their intrinsic nature is eternally existent.
The World-Honored One said:
You say there is an effect, and I also say there is.
You say there is no cause, that is a foolish argument.
World-Honored One, if you encounter a non-Buddhist with the view of annihilationism, they say all dharmas have a cause but no effect.
Because there is no effect, in the future there will be annihilation.
The World-Honored One said:
You say there is a cause, and I also say there is.
You say there is no effect, that is a foolish argument.
The Buddha allows one side of the two arguments, avoiding annihilation and permanence, and speaks of the Middle Way.
Therefore, he says:
I do not argue with the world,
but the world argues with me.
Moreover, the World-Honored One is a speaker of the Dharma,
while the non-Buddhists are speakers of non-Dharma.
A speaker of the Dharma is by nature free from argument,
while a speaker of non-Dharma is by nature full of argument.
Moreover, the Buddha, in the conventional, follows the world, but in the ultimate truth, he does not follow the Buddha.
Moreover, the World-Honored One is good at cutting off the two roots of argument.
The two roots of argument
are desire and views.
Because the Buddha has permanently severed [afflictions], he is said to be without conflict.
Because worldly [beings] have not severed [afflictions], they are said to have conflict.
The Venerable One said:
The World-Honored One is a proponent of the doctrine of suchness.
The non-Buddhist paths are proponents of the doctrine of non-suchness.
Proponents of the doctrine of suchness are by nature without conflict.
Proponents of the doctrine of non-suchness are by nature in conflict, like a horse stepping on dangerous ground, with steps that are low and high.
If one travels on level ground, one's steps are without difference or deviation.
Moreover, because the Buddha sees the meaning, sees the Dharma, sees the good, and is well-tamed, he is said to be without conflict.
The worldly [beings] are not like this, so they are said to have conflict.
Question: Why is it called wrong view?
Answer: Because of wrongly judging, it is called wrong view.
Question: If that is so, then all five views are wrongly judging.
Why is only this called wrong view?
Answer: Because it is established by a separate mode of appearance.ğŸ”½The separate mode of appearance
refers to the mode of appearance of non-existence.
If it is not established by this,
then all five types should be called wrong view.
Because the five views are all wrong judgments.
However, because the characteristics and faults of wrong views are especially serious,
only on the basis of this are they established as the name of wrong views. Furthermore, if wrong judgment also destroys things, it is called wrong view.
Although the remaining four views are wrong judgments, they do not destroy things, so they are established as having separate names.
Furthermore, if wrong judgment denies cause and effect, it is called wrong view.
Although the remaining four views are wrong judgments, they do not deny cause and effect, so they are established as having separate names.
Furthermore, if wrong judgment is extremely contrary to giving, morality, and cultivation, it is called wrong view.
The remaining views are not like this, so they are established as having separate names.
Furthermore, if wrong judgment denies the perfect enlightenment, the Three Jewels, and those who take refuge in the present, past, and future, it is called wrong view.
The remaining views are not like this, so they are established as having separate names.
Furthermore, if wrong judgment destroys the two kinds of kindness, it is called wrong view.
The remaining views are not like this, so they are established as having separate names. The two kinds of kindness are:
1. the kindness of the Dharma, 2. the kindness of birth.
The one who destroys the Dharma's kindness.
Refers to the absence of giving,
the absence of love and joy,
the absence of sacrifice, the absence of good conduct,
the absence of evil conduct,
the absence of the ripening of the results of good and evil actions,ğŸ”½the absence of this world,
and the absence of the next world.
The one who destroys the kindness of birth.
Refers to the absence of father, the absence of mother,
the absence of the world of sentient beings born through transformation,
and the absence of true arhats who have attained right practice.
And so on, in detail.
Furthermore, if one wrongly speculates and gives rise to two kinds of resentment, it is called wrong view.
The other views are not like this, so they are established separately.
The one who gives rise to two kinds of resentment.
One gives rise to resentment towards the Dharma,
and two gives rise to resentment towards birth.
The one who gives rise to resentment towards the Dharma.
Refers to saying there is no giving, and so on, in detail.
The one who gives rise to resentment towards birth.
Refers to saying there are no parents, and so on, in detail.
Furthermore, if one wrongly speculates and destroys direct perception, it is called wrong view.
The other views are not like this, so they are established separately.
It is like a person who has fallen into a blazing pit of fire.
Deceiving the world, they say they experience pleasure.
Sentient beings with wrong views are also like this.
Dwelling in various aggregates, realms, and sense bases of suffering, their minds are entangled by wrong views, saying I have no suffering.
Those who speak like this
are said to destroy direct perception.
Furthermore, if wrong speculation is called violent and evil, it is called wrong view.
As a sutra says, Bhiká¹£us should know,
for those with wrong views, according to the power of their views, all their bodily actions, verbal actions, thoughts, aspirations, and practices,
and all their kinds lead to unlovable, unlikable, unpleasant, and disagreeable results.
Why is this?
Because that wrong view is a violent and evil view.
The remaining four views, although they are wrong speculations, are not violent and evil, so they are established as separate [views].
Question: Why is it called the grasping of views?
Answer: Because this grasps various views, it is called the grasping of views.
Question: This grasps the five aggregates of clinging.
Why is it only called the grasping of views?
Answer: Because this cause takes the five aggregates in general, it is only called the view of holding to an inferior view as supreme.
Next, by what characteristics is the name of the view of holding to an inferior view as supreme established?
It is said that if one takes a view or takes the other aggregates and holds them to be supreme, it is called the view of holding to an inferior view as supreme.
Next, this should be called the view of holding to an inferior view as supreme and so forth.
Omitting the word and so forth, it is only called the view of holding to an inferior view as supreme.
Next, because it often takes views, it is called the view of holding to an inferior view as supreme.
Question: Why is it called the view of holding to mere rules and ritual as supreme?
Answer: Because this view takes mere rules and ritual, it is called the view of holding to mere rules and ritual.
Question: This view takes the five aggregates in general.
Why is it only called the view of holding to mere rules and ritual?
Answer: Because this cause takes the five aggregates in general due to mere rules and ritual,
it is only called the view of holding to mere rules and ritual.
Next, it is called the view of holding to mere rules and ritual because of its mode of activity.
That is to say, taking mere rules and ritual or taking the other aggregates and holding them to be able to purify is called the view of holding to mere rules and ritual.
Next, this view should be called the view of holding to mere rules and ritual and so forth.
Omitting the word and so forth,
it is only called the view of holding to mere rules and ritual.
Furthermore, it is called the grasping of precepts and vows because it grasps many precepts and vows.
It is called the grasping of precepts and vows.
Why are the two views both called grasping?
Because these two views arise with the mode of grasping, they are both called grasping.
The view of the existence of a self grasps a self and what belongs to a self. The view of grasping extremes grasps annihilation and permanence.
Wrong views grasp non-existence.
Grasping these views as supreme is called the grasping of views.
Grasping precepts and vows as able to attain purity is called the grasping of precepts and vows.
Furthermore, the first three views have a strong and sharp power in inferring and judging their objects, so they are called views.
The last two views have a strong and sharp power in grasping and holding their objects, so they are called grasping.
There are six bodies of craving.
The body of craving born from eye contact.
The body of craving born from ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind contact.
Thus, the body of craving should be said to be of one kind.

For example, among the seven latent afflictions, desire in the desire realm is established as the latent affliction of craving for desire.

Question: Why did the World-Honored One extensively explain one craving, etc.,
but concisely explain the six bodies of craving, etc., without explaining immeasurable craving, etc.?
Answer: It is because of the basis.
That is to say, from one craving up to immeasurable craving,

there is none that does not arise from the six faculties, six doors, six stages, six steps, six traces, six paths, and six groups, and is associated with the six consciousnesses. Therefore, it is only said to be six.
Question: Hatred and ignorance are also based on the six faculties, and so on up to being associated with the six consciousnesses.
Why did the World-Honored One speak of the six bodies of craving but not speak of the six bodies of hatred and the six bodies of ignorance?
Answer: Although it should be explained, it is not explained.
One should know that there is a remainder to this meaning.
Moreover, since the bodies of craving have already been explained, one should know that the basis, etc., of the bodies of hatred and ignorance have also been explained.
Moreover, craving pervades the three realms and occurs independently in the six consciousnesses, so it is called a body.
Although hatred also occurs independently in the six consciousnesses,
it does not pervade the three realms. Although ignorance also pervades the three realms,ğŸ”½it is not independent.
But since it does not occur independently and is found in all six consciousnesses, it is not called a body.
Moreover, craving is found in all three realms and occurs independently in all six consciousnesses.
Ordinary beings and noble ones alike can manifest it, so it is called a body.
Although aversion also occurs independently in all six consciousnesses,
ordinary beings and noble ones alike can manifest it,
it is not found in all three realms.
Although ignorance is found in all three realms,
ordinary beings and noble ones alike can manifest it, it does not occur independently in all six consciousnesses, so it is not called a body.
Moreover, craving can distinguish the various realms, stages, and types of afflictions, and can also give rise to all afflictions, so it is established as a body.
Aversion and ignorance do not have such functions, so they are not called bodies.
Question: Why is it called a body?
Answer: Because many cravings accumulate, it is called a body.
That is to say, the craving produced by eye contact in a single moment is not called the body of craving produced by eye contact.
Many moments of eye contact-born craving are called the aggregate of craving born of eye contact. Up to the aggregate of craving born of mind contact is also like this.
Just as a single elephant is not called an elephant army,
only when many elephants gather is it called an elephant army.
The horse army and foot army should be understood in the same way.
Therefore, many cravings are called the aggregate of craving. Question: The view of self-existence and so forth also accumulate in large numbers, so they should be called the aggregate.
Why is it said to be only craving?
Answer: The view of self-existence and so forth should also be called the aggregate.
But not speaking of it is a partial explanation.
Furthermore, the view of self-existence and so forth are only in the mental ground and not in the five consciousnesses, so they are not called the aggregate.
Question: Shamelessness, lack of conscience, torpor, and restlessness also pervade the six consciousnesses. Why are they not called the aggregate?
Answer: They should also be called the aggregate, but not speaking of it,
one should know that this is a partial explanation.
Furthermore, the previous explanation that pervades the three realms and the solitary one pervading the six consciousnesses is called the aggregate.
Although torpor and restlessness are found in all three realms, they are not independent and are found in all six consciousnesses, so they are not called bodies.
Shamelessness and lack of conscience lack both meanings, so they are not called bodies.
Moreover, the latent tendencies are subtle and their power is strong, so they can be called bodies.
The entanglements and defilements are coarse and unstable, and their power is weak, so they are not called bodies.
Moreover, it was said earlier that craving can distinguish the various realms, levels, and categories, so it is called a body.
The afflicted views of self and so on do not have this meaning and are not even called bodies.
